In the same sheet, close packing effects cause more stabilization via H-bonds; 2.553-3.015 Å, Table 3, electrostatic cation-π contacts; Cu(1)-C(5) = 3.038 Å, and π-π stacking; 3.266-3.592 Å, Table 4. On the other hand, the 2D-sheets related to the translation in the a axis direction, are stacked in an ⋯A⋯A⋯A⋯ fashion and build up a 3D-network structure, Fig. 3. These parallel sheets along the a axis are close packed by extensive H-bonds developing the 3D-network structure. It is worth mentioned that the dmqox molecules are arranged quite parallel along the b axis with a separation distance 9.369 Å. However, interweaving of the sheets create two sets of the parallel dmqox ligands which are alternatively arranged in the parallel sheets where the angle between two dmqox molecules crossing each other in neighboring sheets is 51.16°, Fig. 3. The distance between the parallel sets of dmqox ligands along the b axis is 9.784 Å while the distance between the parallel sheets along the a axis is 4.262 Å which exceeds those observed in the prototype [Cu2(CN)2⋅qox]2, 3, [11] to adopt wide space enough to accommodate the more bulky dmqox molecules. The dmqox ligands in the ⋯A⋯A⋯A⋯ pattern along the a axis look like swords directed from one sheet to the next sheet forming extensive H-bonds between the H-atoms of the dmqox ligands and the cyanide groups with distances in the range of 2.941-3.292 Å, Table 3. Thus, the 3D-network structure of 1 is close packed via hydrogen bonding while π-π stacking and/or Cu-Cu interactions are avoided which is not the case for the prototype SCP \documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{qox}}} \right]_{ 2} $$\end{document} containing the less bulky qox ligand.

Interestingly, the XRPD pattern calculated from the X-ray single crystal data of SCP 1 is different than that of the prototype \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{qox}}} \right]_{ 2}; $$\end{document}3, in spite of the fact that both compounds exhibit an ⋯A⋯A···A··· fashion. This diversity is due to the fact that 3 contains more distorted [Cu6(CN)4(qox)2] rings than 1 due to the presence of the bifurcated cyanide groups as well as the twisting of the qox rings to a certain degree. Also, the sheets in 1 are close packed only by H-bonds while in 3, Cu···Cu interactions (3.045 Å) represent obviously efficient bridging between the A···A sheets. On the other hand, interweaving of the sheets in both compounds, causes stabilization of the 3D-network structure, however in 3 the presence of the [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] fragments leads to bridge the interwoven 2D-sheets via Cu(3)–C(31)\ and Cu(3)···Cu(3) interactions.

This diversity is due to the fact that 3 contains more distorted [Cu6(CN)4(qox)2] rings than 1 due to the presence of the bifurcated cyanide groups as well as the twisting of the qox rings to a certain degree. Also, the sheets in 1 are close packed only by H-bonds while in 3, Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions (3.045 Å) represent obviously efficient bridging between the A⋅⋅⋅A sheets. On the other hand, interweaving of the sheets in both compounds, causes stabilization of the 3D-network structure, however in 3 the presence of the [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] fragments leads to bridge the interwoven 2D-sheets via Cu(3)-C(31)\ and Cu(3)⋅⋅⋅Cu(3) interactions.

elements.content: The presence of the ternary adducts, Ph3Sn+ cation, Cun(CN)m building block and dmqox, in the structure of \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 4} \cdot \left( {{\text{Ph}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{dmqox}}} \right], $$\end{document}2 as well as the (CuCN)n fragments and dmqox ligand in the structure of 1 are confirmed by the IR spectra, which display the bands characteristic of these units, Fig. 5 and S1 and S2. The IR spectrum of 2 exhibits mainly medium and strong bands at 3064 and 3047 cm−1 (νCH), 1577, 1516 and 1480 cm−1 (νC=C), 1428 and 1333 cm−1 (δCH) and 732 and 695 cm−1 (γCH), attributed to the phenyl groups of the Ph3Sn connecting units which resemble the bands of Ph3SnCl. In addition to these phenyl characteristic bands, one should not ignore the absorption bands at 1958, 1882, 1818, 1768 and 1705 cm−1 which afford one of the best and most selective methods for the identification of benzene-ring substitution due to overtones. Also, the bands due to νSn–C appear at 563 and 550 cm−1 supporting the presence of the Ph3Sn fragment in the structure of 2. The presence of dmqox in the network structure of 1 and 2 is supported by the bands due to νCH(a), νCH(m), νC=N, νC=C νC–N and γCH, S1 and S2. The bands due to νC=N and νC=C of dmqox exhibit shifts to lower wave numbers than those of dmqox itself supporting the coordination of dmqox ligand to the copper atoms. The Cun(CN)m fragment which represents the main building block of the structure of 1 and 2 absorbs at 2,144 cm−1 for 1 and at 2,113 and 2,085 cm−1 for 2 due to νC≡N. Also, 2 absorbs at 410 and 405 cm−1 while 1 absorbs at 410 cm−1 due to stretching vibrations of the Cu–C bond. Interestingly, the presence of two νC≡N and two νCu–C bands in the IR spectrum of 2 supports the presence of two types of the cyanide ligand in the structure of 2. On the other hand, the νC≡N bands locate at wave numbers higher than the bands of genuine salts of the corresponding [Cu(CN)4]−3 anions [25] indicating the presence of corrugated chains in the network structure of 1 and 2. In the case of 2 the network structure is constructed via Cu2(CN)4 building blocks connected by the Ph3Sn units creating corrugated chains of Sn–N≡C–Cu–C≡N–Sn. Thus, the structure of 2 contains the (CuCN)n fragments, the dmqox ligand as well as the Ph3Sn connecting units. The absence of the bands due to νSn–C in the IR spectrum of 1 indicates that 1 is organotin free compound.

elements.content: The 1H-NMR spectra of 1 and 2 show one sharp singlet peak at 2.66 and 2.65 ppm, respectively which can be assigned to the six protons of the two methyl groups since they are chemically and magnetically equivalent, while the aromatic protons of the dmqox ligand give rise to two broad multiplet peaks at 7.67–7.71 [H (6,7)] and 7.92–7.96 ppm [H (5,8)] as supported by the ratio of the integration of these peaks which equals to 6:3.91, Fig. 6. This assignment was also supported by consulting the 1H-NMR spectrum of dmqox, which exhibits sharp singlet and two multiplets at 2.63, 7.67–7.70 and 7.91–7.93 ppm corresponding to 2CH3, H (6,7) and H (5,8), respectively. The 1H-NMR spectrum of 2 exhibits also, three broad peaks at 7.32, 7.43 and 7.78 ppm due to the absorption of the aromatic protons of the Ph3Sn units [26], S3. These peaks are different in shape and position than those observed in the 1H-NMR spectrum of Ph3SnCl at 7.42–8.01 ppm. This observation indicates participation of the Ph3Sn units in the structure of 2 as connecting units forming TBPY-5 configuration. Thus, 1H-NMR spectra of dmqox, Ph3SnCl, 1 and 2 supported the presence of dmqox in the structures of 1 and 2 and the Ph3Sn units in the structure of 2.

1H-NMR Spectra of 1 and 2

The 1H-NMR spectra of 1 and 2 show one sharp singlet peak at 2.66 and 2.65 ppm, respectively which can be assigned to the six protons of the two methyl groups since they are chemically and magnetically equivalent, while the aromatic protons of the dmqox ligand give rise to two broad multiplet peaks at 7.67-7.71 [H (6,7)] and 7.92-7.96 ppm [H (5,8)] as supported by the ratio of the integration of these peaks which equals to 6:3.91, Fig. 6. This assignment was also supported by consulting the 1H-NMR spectrum of dmqox, which exhibits sharp singlet and two multiplets at 2.63, 7.67-7.70 and 7.91-7.93 ppm corresponding to 2CH3, H (6,7) and H (5,8), respectively. The 1H-NMR spectrum of 2 exhibits also, three broad peaks at 7.32, 7.43 and 7.78 ppm due to the absorption of the aromatic protons of the Ph3Sn units [26], S3. These peaks are different in shape and position than those observed in the 1H-NMR spectrum of Ph3SnCl at 7.42-8.01 ppm. This observation indicates participation of the Ph3Sn units in the structure of 2 as connecting units forming TBPY-5 configuration. Thus, 1H-NMR spectra of dmqox, Ph3SnCl, 1 and 2 supported the presence of dmqox in the structures of 1 and 2 and the Ph3Sn units in the structure of 2.

elements.content: The 13C-NMR spectrum of 1 displays sharp signals at 23.66, 128.89, 129.67, 141.16, 141.27, 154.77 and 154.89 ppm while that of 2 displays sharp signals at 23.66, 128.58, 128.89, 129.20, 129.67, 129.95, 136.92, 141.30, 143.07 and 154.89 ppm, Fig. 7 and S4. The 13C-NMR spectra of 1 and 2 show mainly the signals due to the resonance of dmqox and the cyanide ligands while the spectrum of 2 shows also the signals due to the resonance of the Ph3Sn connecting units, Fig. 7. The signals at 23.66 (Me), 128.89 (C6 and C7), 129.67 (C5 and C8), 141.27–141.30 (C9 and C10) and 154.89 (C2 and C3) ppm correspond to the resonance of the dmqox which appear at more or less the same position as those of dmqox itself. On the other hand, the signals at 129.20, 129.95 and 136.92 ppm due to the Ph3Sn connecting fragments, in the spectrum of 2, appear at more or less the same position as those of the Ph3Sn fragment itself. The last sharp signal at 136.92 ppm exhibits two satellites at 136.47 and 137.37 ppm due to coupling with 117Sn and 119Sn nuclei. The cyanide ligand, in 1, absorbs at 141.16 and 154.77 ppm in spite of the fact that the structure of 1 contains one type of the cyanide ligand. These two sharp signals appearing in the cyanide region are probably due, in part, to second order effects arising from dipolar coupling to the quadrupolar 14N nucleus [27]. The presence of one type of the cyanide ligand in the structure of 1 is supported by the crystallographic data (vide supra). On the other hand, the cyanide ligand, in 2, absorbs at 128.58 and 143.07 ppm which resemble these observed in the 13C-NMR spectrum of \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 4} \cdot \left( {{\text{Ph}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{qox}}} \right], $$\end{document}4 [6] indicating the presence of the cyanide ligand involved in the formation of the unique rhombic [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] motif and the cyanide ligand in the corrugated chain [CN–Ph3Sn–NC–Cu–CN], respectively. Thus, the 13C-NMR spectrum of the SCP 2 supports the fact that the network structure of 2 contains the rhombic [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] motif. The presence of the [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] fragments in 2 and 4 can be considered as an essential phenomenon in constructing such SCP which acquire large space to accommodate the organic voluminous ligands [13]. The crystallographic data of 4 support this opinion where the expanded structure of 4 contains two non-equivalent cyanide ligands [6]. Also, the NMR data indicate that dmqox ligands play the role of connecting the corrugated chains of [CN–Ph3Sn–NC–Cu–CN] via the copper (I) atoms.

elements.content: The ESI+ mass spectrum of 1 exhibits the base peak at m/z 158 corresponding to molecular ion of dmqox while the base peak of 2 is observed at 351 corresponding to Ph3Sn+ isotopomer of the molecular ion. Fragmentation of dmqox ion gives rise to peaks at m/z = 50, 76, 102 and 117 due to [C4H2]+, [C6H4]+, [C7H4N]+ and [C8H7N]+, respectively, Scheme 1. The mass spectrum of 1 exhibits the ion peaks at m/z = 338, 674, 1016, 1348 and 1685 corresponding to [Cu2(CN)2dmqox]+ ≡ [M]+, [Cu4(CN)4(dmqox)2]+ ≡ [2M]+, [Cu6(CN)6(dmqox)3]+ ≡ [3M]+, [Cu8(CN)8(dmqox)4]+ ≡ [4M]+ and [Cu10(CN)10(dmqox)5]+ ≡ [5M]+, respectively. These ion peaks indicate the polymeric nature of the SCP 1, S5 and S6. The mass spectrum of 2, S7 and Fig. 8, displays the ion peaks at m/z = 197, 274 and 377 corresponding to PhSn+, Ph2Sn+, Ph3SnCN+, respectively. The mass spectrum shows the mass fragment corresponding to [Cu–dmqox]+ at m/z 222. The mass spectrum shows, also, the ion peaks at m/z = 392, 503, 598, 717, 815 and 909 which can be attributed to the presence of [Cu(CN)2Ph2Sn]+, [Cu2CNPh3Sn]+, [CuCNPh3Sn(dmqox)]+, [Cu2(CN)3Ph3Sn(dmqox)]+, [Cu(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2]+ and [Cu2(CN)3(Ph3Sn)2]+ fragments, respectively. In addition, the ion peaks due to [Cu2(CN)4Ph3Sn(dmqox)PhSn]+, [Cu(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+, [Cu2(CN)3Ph3Sn(dmqox)Ph2Sn]+, [Cu2(CN)4Ph3Sn(dmqox)Ph2Sn]+ and [Cu2(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+ appear at m/z = 938, 973, 991, 1014 and 1034, respectively. Moreover, The peak of [Cu2(CN)4(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+ ion at m/z 1086 is observed confirming the expected (M.W.) which can be considered as a further support of the chemical formula suggested by elemental analysis data. In addition, an ion peak at m/z 1154 is observed due to [Cu2(CN)4(Ph3Sn)2PhSnCN]+.

Mass Spectra of 1 and 2

The ESI+ mass spectrum of 1 exhibits the base peak at m/z 158 corresponding to molecular ion of dmqox while the base peak of 2 is observed at 351 corresponding to Ph3Sn+ isotopomer of the molecular ion. Fragmentation of dmqox ion gives rise to peaks at m/z = 50, 76, 102 and 117 due to [C4H2]+, [C6H4]+, [C7H4N]+ and [C8H7N]+, respectively, Scheme 1. The mass spectrum of 1 exhibits the ion peaks at m/z = 338, 674, 1016, 1348 and 1685 corresponding to [Cu2(CN)2dmqox]+ ≡ [M]+, [Cu4(CN)4(dmqox)2]+ ≡ [2M]+, [Cu6(CN)6(dmqox)3]+ ≡ [3M]+, [Cu8(CN)8(dmqox)4]+ ≡ [4M]+ and [Cu10(CN)10(dmqox)5]+ ≡ [5M]+, respectively. These ion peaks indicate the polymeric nature of the SCP 1, S5 and S6. The mass spectrum of 2, S7 and Fig. 8, displays the ion peaks at m/z = 197, 274 and 377 corresponding to PhSn+, Ph2Sn+, Ph3SnCN+, respectively. The mass spectrum shows the mass fragment corresponding to [Cu-dmqox]+ at m/z 222. The mass spectrum shows, also, the ion peaks at m/z = 392, 503, 598, 717, 815 and 909 which can be attributed to the presence of [Cu(CN)2Ph2Sn]+, [Cu2CNPh3Sn]+, [CuCNPh3Sn(dmqox)]+, [Cu2(CN)3Ph3Sn(dmqox)]+, [Cu(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2]+ and [Cu2(CN)3(Ph3Sn)2]+ fragments, respectively. In addition, the ion peaks due to [Cu2(CN)4Ph3Sn(dmqox)PhSn]+, [Cu(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+, [Cu2(CN)3Ph3Sn(dmqox)Ph2Sn]+, [Cu2(CN)4Ph3Sn(dmqox)Ph2Sn]+ and [Cu2(CN)2(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+ appear at m/z = 938, 973, 991, 1014 and 1034, respectively. Moreover, The peak of [Cu2(CN)4(Ph3Sn)2(dmqox)]+ ion at m/z 1086 is observed confirming the expected (M.W.) which can be considered as a further support of the chemical formula suggested by elemental analysis data. In addition, an ion peak at m/z 1154 is observed due to [Cu2(CN)4(Ph3Sn)2PhSnCN]+.

elements.content: Spectroscopic data and elemental analyses show that 2 has the chemical formula \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 4} \cdot \left( {{\text{Ph}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{dmqox}}} \right] $$\end{document} which is the same as that of 4, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 4} \cdot \left( {{\text{Ph}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}}} \right)_{ 2} \cdot {\text{qox}}} \right] $$\end{document} [6]. The experimental X-ray powder and simulated diffractograms of 2 and 4, respectively, have the same reflections, 2θ values and the lattice constants, Fig. 10 indicating that they are isostructural. Thus, the network structure of 2 exhibits two different tetrahedral copper (1) sites forming two Cu(CN)2 building blocks bridged by the Ph3Sn units to create elongated corrugated chains. These chains are connected by the dmqox molecules creating 3D-network structure which contains four rhombic [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] motifs as gathered from the IR and 13C-NMR spectra of 2 (vide supra). The tin sites are coordinated to three phenyl groups and two cyanide ligands in axial positions via coordinate bonds forming TBPY-5 configuration. The network structure of the SCP 2 can be considered as consisting of repeating units of the [Cu2(μ3-CN)2] motifs connected by the CN–Sn–NC spacer on one side and by the dmqox spacer on the other side forming 3D-network. In this case, three different kinds of rings are formed. The 3D-network structure of SCP 2 acquires non-interpenetrating rings creating box-like structure with cavities suitable to accommodate the bulky phenyl groups Scheme 2.

all these SCP is 2:2:1 (Cu:CN:L) while the Cu(1) sites aquire TP-3 geometry. On the other hand, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{CuCN}}\left( { 2{\text{-}} {\text{Mepyz}}} \right)} \right], $$\end{document}12 [17] and \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {\text{CuCN}}{\left( 4{\text{-} {\text{Mepym}}} \right)} \right], $$\end{document}13 [17] have a stoichiometric ratio of 1:1:1 with T-4 Cu(1) sites which lead to the construction of 3D-frameworks. All these SCP contain 1D-infinite [CuCN] chains as a characteristic substructure whereas they are linked by the ligand spacers into sheets. The dimensionality is highly affected by the capability of the ligand to form H-bonds and π–π stacking. However, the shape and size of the ligands affect significantly the topology of the network structure. The occurrence of positional disorder in the ligand substitution pattern of sheets in the structures of 5 and 6 was found to prevent the macroscopic adoption of a chiral or polar space group for these networks that contain such bridging bidentate pyrazine derivatives [17, 18]. On the other hand, the structure of 12 containing the 2-Mepyz ligand induces the adoption of a chiral coordination framework. For the monodentate pyridine derivatives 2D-frameworks are obtained while the structures containing bidentate ligands such as pyz, mpym, Mepyz and qox exhibit 3D-frameworks. So, it is evident that the large size and the bidentate nature of the ligand cause interpenetration or the formation of box-like structures containing large cavities (pores) capable to accommodate the bulky ligands and to encapsulate, in some cases, guest molecule such as in 6 and 8. The structures of 1 and 3 consists of interwoven 2D-sheets forming 3D-network via extensive H-bonds in 1 and Cu···Cu contacts by the formation of the [Cu2(μ-CN)2] motif in 3. The structures create enough space to accommodate dmqox or qox. On the other hand, in spite of the fact that a lot of CuCN complexes with nitrogen bases have been reported, the possibility of obtaining similar arrays containing organotin fragment has been much less extensively studied. However, the structures of 2 and 4 may be compared with those of the formal congeners described as [Cun(CN)m(R3Sn) ×L]. It is evident that the structures of these SCP exhibit great diversity depending on the shape and size of the ligand as well as the type of the organotin fragment. In this aspect, planar sheets involving both 4- and 24-atomic rings are interlinked in \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{CuCN}} \cdot {\text{Me}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}} \cdot 0. 5 {\text{bpy}}} \right] $$\end{document} by almost perpendicular bpy pillars to generate a very voluminous 3D-framework [13]. On the other hand, \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{CuCN}} \cdot {\text{Me}}_{ 3} {\text{SnCN}} \cdot {\text{cpy}}} \right] $$\end{document} crystallizes in a distorted-diamondoid structure with four equivalent and independent, interlocking frameworks [13]. Interestingly, the structures of 2 and 4 contain three fused different rings, the rhombic [Cu2(μ-CN)2], the 18-atomic [Cu4(Ph3Sn)2(CN)4(L)2] and the 24-atomic [C8N8Cu4(Ph3Sn)4] rings, which create a non-interpenetrating 3D-network. These rings form a box-like structure with cavities suitable to accommodate the bulky phenyl groups. Also, the structure of \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ ^{ 3}_{\infty } \left[ {{\text{Cu}}_{ 2} \left( {\text{CN}} \right)_{ 3} {\text{Me}}_{ 3} {\text{Sn}} \cdot {\text{qox}}} \right] $$\end{document} consists of interwoven 2D-layers containing fused distorted polygons forming open 3D-network [10].

elements.content: Two important features can be observed regarding these structures that on going from short to long and from rigid (cpy, qox, dmqox, bpy) to flexible (bpe, bpeH2) ligands non-interpenetrating framework is favorable with the formation, in most cases, of box-like structure as well as the formation of the rhombic [Cu2(μ-CN)2] motif. The short and rigid ligands form, usually interpenetrating frameworks or host–guest systems to fill the space demanded by the framework structure. On the other hand, the flexible and/or bulky ligands adopt unique arrangements of the network structure to avoid crowding and steric hindrance. In such case, the presence of repeating unites of the rhombic [Cu2(μ-CN)2] motif create a 3D-network containing wide spacing, mostly in the shape of a box-like structure, which is enough to accommodate the bulky ligands. Thus, the rhombic [Cu2(μ-CN)2] motifs can be considered as the basic building blocks in the structures of the SCP containing such bulky ligands.

cln_elements.content:
A solution of 180 mg (0.63 mmol) of K3[Cu(CN)4] in 10 mL H2O was added, with gentle stirring to a solution of 378 mg (1.9 mmol) of Me3SnCl and 99 mg (0.63 mmol) of dmqox, in 20 mL acetonitrile. Already, after 4 weeks, red prismatic crystals started growing from the initially clear solution. After filtration, washing with small quantities of cold H2O and acetonitrile and overnight drying, 68 mg (32% referred to K3[Cu(CN)4]) of the red prismatic crystals were obtained. All attempts for the synthesis of 1 in absence of Me3SnCl were unsuccessful under the used experimental conditions. Elemental analysis: Calc. for C12H10N4Cu2 (%): C, 42.72; H, 2.96; N, 16.61; Cu, 37.71, Found: C, 42.63; H, 3.05, N, 16.52; Cu, 37.59.

A solution of 90 mg (0.31 mmol) of K3[Cu(CN)4] in 5 mL H2O was added drop wise, with gentle stirring to a solution of 366 mg (0.95 mmol) of Ph3SnCl and 50 mg (0.31 mmol) of dmqox, in 10 mL of hot acetonitrile. A yellow precipitate was formed at once. After filtration, subsequent washing with small portions of H2O and acetonitrile and overnight drying, about 314 mg (93.4% referred to K3[Cu(CN)4]) of yellow precipitate was obtained. All attempts to grow single crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray studies have so far ended up with the formation of microcrystalline powder. Elemental analysis: Calc. for C50H40N6Cu2Sn2 (%): C, 55.24; H, 3.68; N, 7.73; Cu, 11.69, Found: C, 55.33; H, 3.62, N, 7.67; Cu, 11.56.
